title: Thursday, 29th March, 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas morning
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hello!

Soundbuy Morning
BE11:05am

Welcome, hi there, hey, etc. This is Markets Live.

BE11:05am

Last session before Easter.

vonB Morning
MnM Allo'
Flaneur So conviviality going under. Along with (my local) computer games chain with ~70 stores in the NW - Grainger Games. Supposedly phone shops yday and told them not to open. End of. Retail in a death spiral.
11:06 am
BE11:06am

And predictably quiet, apart from the mountain of M&A and the profit warnings and and and and and

Markkus morning all
Mouselet Good morning
Soundbuy Do we all receive ROTR virtual eggs?
Manxish Morning
Lemmy Busy weekend for a lot of M&A bankers and lawyers, eating their eggs at their desks
BE11:07am

I'm not in the office, incidentally. Want to see where I am?

Mouselet Surely today is the day that we receive 92 pence
Mouselet Where is Bryce?
BE11:07am

Soundbuy Park bench?
11:08 am
BE11:08am

... actually, I'm not. I'm in Dundee. But I was in Edinburgh an hour ago and it's rather more photogenic.

Mouselet Computer-games chains ought nowadays to have roughly the same economics as second-hand bookshops
Fox Bradford?
Flaneur 'But why now', I hear you all cry.Ive been 'down' on comm prop for some and with good reason - retail is leading the way, light industrial will follow soon.
BE11:08am

Anyway, enough of the holiday snaps. Where do we start?

Mouselet there's no reason to buy a new computer game other than from Amazon, but old computer games are quite a good competitor to new computer games
Blank canvas a reminder to Melrose/GKN supporters and our US readers, some people celebrate today as Smoke and Mirrors Day.https://www.daysoftheyear.com/days/2018/03/29/
Mouselet what does light industrial even *mean* nowadays?
undefined
11:09 am
BE11:09am

NEX? I mean, it was done at length in the papers this morning, but we can at least note it.

NEX Group PLC (NXG:LSE): Last: 968.00, down 4 (-0.41%), High: 982.00, Low: 947.50, Volume: 5.07m
pfd Not a bad end to Spencer's career.
BE11:10am

£10 a share, 50% stock and 50% cash ......

wayneJ @Mouselet - I assume you don't play console games. And do not use Steam?
Mouselet I do play console games, I buy the bluray off Amazon and then get mildly annoyed when it contains an installer and I have to wait 24 hours for the download
11:11 am
BE11:11am

..... We'd been hearing all week a price of "about" £10.40, which I think is what the ratio would've been had CME not had a rough session yesterday.

Mouselet I did buy the console at a physical Game store this time round
Mouselet I don't have a Windows PC, and tend to game on the XBox rather than the Mac
Flaneur The reason this is happening now is that the Q rent is due and firms that cannot pay, simply fold.(@Mouselet - distribution, manufacturing, large-ish services)Fly posters/bills starting to appear around Manchester decrying 'greedy landlords killing your business'.Comes to something when the shopkeepers are sloganeering....(will post a photo after easter)
BE11:11am

Only question remaining, I guess, is whether this is the end of it.

Edward Quince I got burned by the previous collapse of GAME, so I stay well-clear of game shops in general.
wayneJ Incidentally I am wondering if we are going past peak Amazon, peak Facebook and peak Google? My wife has been buying stuff online in the last week and it has been noticeable how eg the sizes we want are not available on Amazon or the prices are more expensive than other retailers.
BE11:13am

Spencer jumping over to the CME board, plus the 80% or 90% premium on the undisturbed price, makes a counter look pretty unlikely you'd have thought.

Mouselet Amazon has never been terribly good for clothing
Flaneur @EQ - this is one of those game shops with the window full of 2nd hand phones.
Sails The fly posters have a point though; retail rents have has ratchet clauses (rent can only go up) for ages. Some businesses could be sustainable at lower rents. Landlords will have to swallow it
Edward Quince Ah, right. Yeah, that seems a low-rent type of operation.
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Here's the ever-excellent Olivetree.

BE11:14am

A see through price of 1000p is towards the top end of valuations for this asset and whereas it is impossible to rule out a third party from interloping, the body language of today’s announcement seems to suggest that this is the end of a process rather than the start of one. NXG has genuinely interesting assets, names ranging from LSE to Deutsche Boerse have all been linked in the past, so it will come as no surprise to see the stock trade very tightly to the offer price as the market looks for low-risk optionality here. Indeed the timing of the Scheme meeting seems to indicate that (to some degree) CME are worried about the concept of giving any third parties time to think about competing. But the structure of Michael Spencer’s irrevocable and the underlying valuation would hint that such interloping is probably unlikely – it seems that Spencer has decided that CME is the best option here. The flip side of CME looking to rush through a Scheme meeting is that NXG (and Spencer) have agreed to this, so they must be happy the optionality they are giving up isn’t that valuable. Granted the irrevocables do indeed fall away if a 3rd party offer becomes unconditional – and with only 16% locked up with CME, that third party could “just” structure an Offer with a minimum 50% acceptance level and still win. However, at the margin it would be strange for someone to have failed to make their interest known to Spencer thus far, and then have to make such a cumbersome Offer in the future to win this asset – the hint in today’s announcement would seem to be that the overwhelming likelihood is that this asset will now transact to CME as planned.

Mouselet I keep forgetting that small businesses on high-street type things generally don't own their premises
Edward Quince So, what effect on commercial real estate funds? Should they take lower rents, or let the shops sit empty until the charity shops move in?
wayneJ Also I have been looking at the tax paid by internet companies within the UK /EU and I wonder if a significant part of their differentiation comes down to tax 'optimisation'. I wonder if a better govt policy would be any company avoiding taxes losses protection from the courts for its IP and assets....:-)
pfd any shop needs to take £1000 a week just to survive.
BE11:15am

Though I note the argument going around that another bidder could plausibly offer more cash.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

As per Justin Bates at Liberum.

BE11:16am

Following the confirmation that CME was entertaining a bid for NEX we suggested a take-out price of c.900p and in the event of a competitive situation, which we viewed as likely, then a price of +1000p was not unreasonable. CME has this morning bid 1000p, clearly aiming to deter any competitive threat. It is comprised of 500p cash + 500p in CME stock (0.0444 CME shares). NEX shareholders will also be entitled to the March'18 final DPS, to be no more than 7.65p. The bid values NEX on a FY19 (March YE) PE of 26.9x, falling to 23.4x, a CY19 PE of 24.2x. This is a good price. However, the 50% cash component might be a little disappointing for some (CME shares trade on a CY18 PE of 24.5x, falling to 22.8x) and thus leave the door ajar for a competing offer with a higher cash component. We do not discount this but the absolute level of 1000p makes it less likely than we thought before today.

Soundbuy These pension Cos. must be sitting on massive retail estates valued at well over 'real' current mkt values.......
BE11:16am

Is there a break fee involved, BTW? I only glanced at the statement but didn't see anything.

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:18am

ROTR into retail, which I guess is in reaction to Conviviality's pretty spectacular failure.

Flaneur The problem is that rents and valuations are a function of each other.Once one goes, the whole thing goes and any loans against them start to look very shaky.I have been droning on about people moving money and property around in SIPP funds for some time.... its very clear from these movements that there is significant financial stress in large swathes of the country.
BE11:18am

We're still unclear what exactly has happened here, but it's worth emphasising that it's not just another "woe on the high street" story.

wayneJ Property companies (whether owned by pension funds or others ) face a dilemma - if they reduce the rent in a shop then the valuers lower the value and other tenants also demand cuts. So they end up with empty properties. OR they give incentives such as 'fit out costs' or 'rent free' but then ask the valuer to base the valuation on 'normalised rent'. Additionally a lot of pension / insurance funds are 'passive' investors in property and have massively underinvested in maintaining the economic earning power of their estate.
Paper Chase I'd love to see an analysis of the Conviviality debacle. It's bizarre and fascinating.
Mouselet Oh dear, I hadn't realized they owned Bibendum
11:19 am
BE11:19am

The news, in case you're behind, is that Conviviality's going to call in the administrators after failing to get a £125m equity raise away.

DJ is there any legal recourse against the Conviviality board here?
rw42 Think limited market for 2nd hand computer games - most are a key on steam/battle.net/origin etc, having the physical media means nothing if you can't transfer the license!
Mouselet I'm not sure about that 'most' part - I buy physical media second-hand precisely for transferrable license reasons
RA hey you crazy kids. looks like much to catch up on
Soundbuy Will the likes of Booker be eyeing the CVR carcass?
BE11:20am

N+1 incoming .....

BE11:20am

Conviviality through its Matthew Clark and Bibbendum subsidiaries is the dominant on-trade supplier to the UK hospitality sector, serving around 23,000 outlets out of a market size of c.45,000. It was thus in the hospitality and drink manufacturers interest that Conviviality secured the necessary funding, both from a supply and competitive pricing perspective. The fact that it has not will have clear short term supply issues for both sectors. Given wider consumer and cost related challenges currently facing the sector and the significance of Easter trading this is clearly a negative of varying degrees for the quoted pubs & restaurant sector. Our understanding is that the majority, if not all, of the pubs and restaurant stocks have exposure to Conviviality in terms of drinks supplies.

Soundbuy *up
11:21 am
BE11:22am

I mean, it's negative-ish? But we're not suggesting that the trade is going to fail to find another booze wholesaler, surely?

Puntino Time to buy Majestic?
vonB Conviviality is in a way a repeat of the Palmer & Harvey collapse, underscoring the fragile nature of the pub & restaurant trade
BE11:23am

..... Here's Shore. Understandably shellshocked.

BE11:23am

Given the retail and wholesale nature of the Group, the franchise business, Bargain Booze
and the major drinks distributor that Matthew Clark is in the UK, there is clearly need for
pace so that the business does not simply fall apart through a lack of product on the
shelves and in the bar, with all of the consequent personal and corporate damage.
We note the group continues to trade at present post a number of inbound enquires
regarding a sale of all or part of the business. We also point out that customers of the
group business can chose to use other suppliers to stock their shelves and suppliers to
Conviviality are likely to have stopped supplying product now for fear to not being paid. All
this puts intense pressure on the business hence the need for some sort of resolution
sooner rather than later.

RA I buy a lot of games of steam. Recently when I have purchased off amazon, they just contain a steam code still!
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Who would be interested in acquiring the group?
As to potential suitors for Conviviality, today’s announcement confirms there is interest and
we believe the interested parties are likely to be from different market segments. The
complication for us is likely to be how many would be interested in the group in its current
structure to enable a quick sale.
Depending on due diligence, we believe private equity could be an acquirer of the entire
group assuming it sees Conviviality’s issues as operational ones that are fixable and
confidence could be rebuilt in its customer and supplier base. The acquisition could be
done with a view for follow selective disposals to help fund any such deal in due course.

Puntino Amazon makes all its money by issuing shares to employees instead of paying them in cash and then selling these on at ridiculous multiples to the market.
Edward Quince (Also, don't forget that often/sometimes/occasionally the shop is owned by the local authority, who seem particularly adept at shooting themselves in the foot with a downward spiral of empty shops -> fewer shoppers -> lower sales in other shops --> rinse and repeat.
BE11:25am

(@vonB: I think yes and no. Conviviality's discovery of a £30m tax bill, its failure to add up numbers properly and its shambolic handling of the profit warnings are probably at least as significant to suppliers and shareholders getting cold feet, I'd suggest.)

BE11:26am

MRW is a perennial underdog in our sector, unloved by the sell-side but with best long term historical TSR and a favourite of value investors. We think it makes for great income stock.

Including last year's special divi on an 83% ratio ....

BE11:33am

We expect them to take it up to 100% for the next few years. Even with higher pay-outs, they are still deleveraging, providing plenty of downside protection. That means divi yield of 6.3% next year, followed by 7.0%, 7.4% and 9.0%.

Edward Quince (in my experience - your local Morrisons might be lovely, etc.)
Gross Loydman The Conviviality BOD share purchases look pretty fishy now...

11:35 am

So, high cash, low beta, but unrecognised by a cold and heartless market that still hears Morrison and thinks of northern dourness and dumb property deals and stupid expansions into online baby kit and etc.

rw42 @wayne - kind of like games workshop i think. You pick up the habit in your teens, and then splash out cash in 20s/30s when you can buy all the kit you want!
BE11:35am

Earnings are steadily being revised upward. That has actually been Morrisons' fate for the last 20 years: it is the only stock where sell-siders systematically upgrade earnings. It is the underdog of food retail, where execution beats strategy.

kim @Edward - I assume that Conviviality is insolvent - you can't trade while insolvent. So it needs a write-down of liabilities, after which a buyer can be found.
BE11:35am

That's that.

undefined

[...] However, given the board’s insistence that the company can roll out its strategy without funding from new investors, that speculation may remain just that: speculation."

undefined

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Pre-Close trading update results in no changes to FY18 forecasts. Small tweak to FY19E estimates to better reflect ANZ implementation. ESMA changes could provide near term uncertainty but company well positioned to be a winner in the medium term. Retain 170p price target and Outperform rating.

BE11:48am

As does Peel Hunt.

Forester Convivality - I would imagine that Matthew Clark will have a lot of interested parties contacting adminstrators
BE11:49am

Currently the shares trade on an (annualised)
Dec’18 EV/EBITDA of 7.7x, a 20% discount to IG and expected to yield almost 6%. Our current valuation already assumes a pessimistic view from impending regulatory changes (with the assumption of a fall in UK/EU revenue of 14% that is greater than the c10% IG is guiding and that’s before mitigating actions). The statement confirms that the proportion of high value clients continues to increase, with the benefit that a large proportion of these customers are likely to be legible for professional status that will exempt them from new regulations. Furthermore, the valuation does not consider the attractions of the business including the ANZ deal (running on track for delivery in September) and the scalability of the platform. Today’s pre-close statement, emphasises the strength of CMC’s platform and we expect to see the shares re-rate as the current regulatory overhang dissipates. We therefore retain our Buy recommendation and target price of 210p.

Forester Game Digital - note that Gfinity has just done a big place to fund next years gaming events...so not exactly profit or cash generating at the moment!
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Weird that we're talking about bookmakers -- because that's what CFD brokers are, let's be honest -- needing customers to lose even more to gain regulatory clearance.

BE11:51am

Much of the regulation around the regular bookmakers has been trying to deter addict punters from spending their life savings. But with CFD and spreads brokers, it seems mandatory that they do.

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 425.50, up 2.5 (+0.59%), High: 429.20, Low: 421.50, Volume: 1.76m

Takeda crapped out nearly 8% last night, which gives a clear view of what its shareholders think about issuing a tonne of paper for a potentially third-rate haemo franchise.

12:00 pm

Sellside continue to identify Pfizer as the most likely of the counterbidders ...... Hm .......

BE12:01pm

Credit Suisse incoming.

Flaneur @Pseudo - Id rather a proper recession than this 10 year long nonsense the BoE have engineered....
LJ @Pseudonym- ironic that it is a 'bull market' and yet everything has been funded on leveraging households. Most 20 y/o driving around in a £50,000 Mercedes putting £5 of fuel in it...
BE12:02pm

Strong GI, Neuroscience & Oncology overlap: In this note, we compare the therapeutic overlap between the two companies
(and thus the level strategic fit and opportunity for cost savings). Takeda points to the transaction as potentially
strengthening its focus in GI, neuroscience and oncology (22% of NPV for Takeda and 18% of NPV for Shire). Specifically,
we see scope for Takeda to do more with Resolor in chronic constipation in the US (CS 20% POS peak $130m), and see
synergies between Shire's ADHD franchise and Takeda's Trintellix (ex paediatric ADHD where Shire is the leader). Takeda
also talk of an interest in rare diseases (greater than 50% of Shire NPV) and improving geographic reach. We estimate Takeda has
28% US exposure stand alone. Including Shire this would increase to 46% proforma, which would bring them in line with
global Major peers (CSe 47% US exposure).

nichoman @Soundbuy: haven't been following Smurfit closely -- are there any other bidders being mentioned there ?
Forester @pseudoym yes agree - lets get it out of the way rather than dragging on!
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Deal Likely Complex: We would not assume typical deal synergies given Shire's lean infrastructure. Relative size is also an
obstacle, with similar market caps but $20bn of Shire debt. CSe Shire's NPV is 2x Takeda's.
 Potential for Strategic Deal vs full bid?: We believe a deal between Shire and Takeda covering neuroscience, GI and
oncology could have strong rationale ($16bn of Shire NPV). Shire is in the process of reviewing ADHD in order to focus on
rare diseases. Other bidders could include PFE (with the required scale), as they have an interest in haemophilia and rare
diseases.

BE12:02pm

Sorry for the lumpy formatting.
